name: I Corinthians Online Trivia | Corinthians (I and II) | 10 Questions

questions.text: What is the first word of I Corinthians in the King James Version?
questions.explanation:
Paul.

	It says in I Corinthians 1:1, "Paul called to be an apostle of Jesus Christ through the will of God, and Sosthenes our brother." I and II Corinthians are the letters that Paul wrote to the church in Corinth. These books (along with the other letters Paul wrote) are known as epistles.

questions.text: What is the problem with Corinth, according to chapter 5?
questions.explanation:
Incest.

	It says in I Corinthians 5:1, "It is reported commonly that there is fornication among you, and such fornication as is not so much as named among the Gentiles, that one should have his father's wife." Corinth is located in Greece. The modern city of Corinth is located about 3km south of the Biblical Corinth.

questions.text: According to I Corinthians 8:9, what should people try not to be toward a weaker Christian?
questions.explanation:
a stumblingblock.

	It says in I Corinthians 8:9, "But take heed lest by any means this liberty of yours become a stumblingblock to them that are weak." Christians believe this verse says that they have to be careful how they live. One doesn't want a new Christian to sin because one did something that shouldn't be done, causing them to think it's okay to do.

questions.text: What kind of crown does Paul say the people who live for Christ will gain?
questions.explanation:
Incorruptible.

	It says in I Corinthians 9:25, "And every man that striveth for the mastery is temperate in all things. Now they do it to obtain a corruptible crown; but we an incorruptible." "Corruptible crowns" refers to things we have on earth that we cannot take with us when we die.  "Incorruptible crowns" refers to our rewards in Heaven.

questions.text: According to I Corinthians 10:13, God will not allow people to be tempted more than what?
options: the amount their best friend is tempted
three or four times a day
questions.explanation:
they are able to bear.

	It says in I Corinthians 10:13, "There hath no temptation taken you but such as is common to man: but God is faithful, who will not suffer you to be tempted above that ye are able; but will with the temptation also make a way to escape, that ye may be able to bear it." Temptation can sometimes feel like we can't say no to it, but God says in this verse that we can avoid giving in to it.

questions.text: How many bodies does the Church have, according to chapter 12?
questions.explanation:
one.

	It says in I Corinthians 12:12, "For as the body is one, and hath many members, and all the members of that one body, being many, are one body: so also is Christ." Christ is considered to be the Head of the Church body, according to Christians.

questions.text: Chapter 13 is known as the love chapter, but what is the word used in the King James Version for "love"?
questions.explanation:
Charity.

	It says in I Corinthians 13.4, "Charity suffereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up." Love is clearly very important, since Paul dedicates such a large section of his letter to the Corinthians to this topic.

questions.text: Why does Paul not place a lot of importance on the gift of tongues?
questions.explanation:
It needs an interpreter.

	It says in I Corinthians 14.5, "I would that ye all spake with tongues but rather that ye prophesied: for greater is he that prophesieth than he that speaketh with tongues, except he interpret, that the church may receive edifying." The gift of tongues is when you can speak in a language that you do not know. However, you won't understand it, and need a person with the gift of interpreting tongues to translate it.

questions.text: How does Paul describe himself in chapter 15?
questions.explanation:
Least of the apostles.

	It says in I Corinthians 15:9, "For I am the least of the apostles, that am not meet to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God." An apostle is one of the disciples who saw Jesus here on earth. There are the original 12, and then Paul because He also saw Jesus on the road to Damascus.

questions.text: How long does Paul say he'll "tarry at Ephesus"?
options: until he is put in prison again
questions.explanation:
until Pentecost.

	It says in I Corinthians 16:8, "But I will tarry at Ephesus until Pentecost." Pentecost is sometimes described as the "church's birthday" according to wikipedia.
